div.sent: By nature's law all human beings grow old one day.
And in old age, people face many problems along with physical weakness in society and family.
These problems are familial, economic, cultural and psychological.
Due to the inability to earn, often the importance of elderly people reduces in family.
They fall victim to many neglect and deprivation.
Due to lack of income, it becomes difficult for them to maintain life, to provide shelter and treatment for themselves.
For this, they have to depend on others or seek help of others.
This creates one kind of inferiority complex in them.
In developed countries of the world, the state or the government creates many facilities for elderly people.
The problems and the rights of the elderly are being considered seriously in our country too.
Some elderly people are there in all our families or among our relatives.
We also find old people in our neighbourhood or meet them while we go out on the streets.
We must realize their difficulties in moving around, crossing roads and getting on transports.
These elderly people were not old all the time.
Once they had done many things for the family and the society.
Now in their old age the society also has some duty and responsibility towards them.
We should remember that we will also grow old one day.
Although the physical capability of elderly people reduces due to old age, they can help us by their knowledge and experience.
In that respect, they are resources of society like other people of any age.
They are valuable human resources.
But first of all, we have to change our attitude to elderly people.
We have to change our mentality of looking down upon them as a burden of society or as useless.
Usually people over 60 are considered the elderly in our country.
It is because after that age, people retire from earning occupations.
The retiring age from government service is This age limit has recently been extended to 65 for judges, university teachers and some particular professions.
It is not that after that age all people lose their ability to work.
But in the developed countries of the world people over 60 or 65 are considered Senior Citizens.
They are offered special honour and facilities in society.
The United Nations has laid some principles to protect the rights of the elderly.
Familial: In the past, families were joint families in our country.
In that time elderly people had some authority and superior positions in the family.
But joint families are breaking into small nuclear families due to industrialization, urbanization and the changes in people's economic life-style.
There is want of people to look after them or to nurse them in sickness.
There are none to give company to them or to talk to them.
As a result, they fall victim to a sort of loneliness and depression.
In old age, these duties often prove difficult to them.
Old people are often considered burden in the family.
Economic: Many elderly people become economically helpless because they have no source of income and their savings and assets are distributed among heirs.
They have to depend on their wards.
They cannot do anything independently.
These problems are higher mostly for old people in middleclass and poor families.
Many people become almost penniless before reaching their old age in the process of maintaining family, spending for children's education and for marrying away daughters.
Many loyse all their properties in natural disasters like floods and high tides and river erosions.
In this condition, for children who have not enough income it becomes difficult for them to look after elderly parents.
Despite their willingness, they cannot look after them properly.
Physical: Physical capability of people reduces in old age.
Many diseases become permanent in body.
At this age people need some relaxation and comfort.
But many elderly people in our country cannot afford to have this comfort.
They even do not get necessary treatment in illness.
They cannot afford to buy food and medicine while sick.
Socio-cultural: The honour once shown to elderly people or the importance given to the opinion of them is no more in our country.
The reasons for this are breakdown of values, lack of moral education, influence of foreign culture and the spread of self- centred attitudes in society.
Elderly people are considered useless in family and in society.
Their opinions are not given importance.
It seems that none has time to sit beside them and listen to them.
They have little opportunity for leisure and recreation.
Psychological: The cornered condition in family and society gives rise to a sense of inferiority complex in the elderly.
They begin to feel ignored and helpless.
Lack of own resources along with physical sickness and loneliness add to this inferiority complex.
Loss of memory in old age also creates additional problems.
